posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked:
We have a couple roborio 2’s and a roborio 1.

We have tried a couple of times to get the roborio 1 running, but with no joy.

Is it possible to use a roborio 1 in 2025 frc in a devolopment robot? (We develop in python).

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: Probably. It was last year. You need to confirm in the Robot rules. It is quite specific
We have all the 2025 software running on a Roborio 1 based on CTRE swerve.

posts.name: Fletch
posts.cooked: Yes, the roborio 1 is still an allowed robot controller.  That said, you may run into memory issues depending on how much you’re asking it to do
Agree.  I would plan on disabling the web server on a Roborio 1.

posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked: Thanks. We won’t use the roborio 1 in competition. I haven’t inspected the rules.

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: I have had no issues with it with the web server enabled or disabled, although that’s for a bot with 8 thrusters and not swerve modules

posts.name: Levi
posts.cooked: Can’t speak to competition legality (although I would imagine it’s legal) but I can definitely confirm that the Rio 1 can run 2025 software since that’s what we test our vendordep on at Lumyn Labs

posts.name: Dustin Spicuzza
posts.cooked: A rio 1 works fine, but is limited in memory. If you’re trying to use pathplannerlib, it requires numpy, which means you need more memory. One way to get more memory is to disable the NI webserver via robotpy installer niweb disable … just make sure to re-enable the webserver if you need to reimage the rio.

posts.name: Bradford Smith
posts.cooked:
I’m unable to find an image for the v1 robo rio in the latest 2025 FRC game tools install (2025 patch 1). I find the FRC_roboRIO_2025_v2.0 image in the installed directory (C:\Program Files (x86)\National Instruments\LabVIEW 2023\project\roboRIO Tool\ FRC Images) but nothing for the v1 roboRIO.

We have a v2 RIO for competition but want to use the v1s for software development and testing, and need to run the 2025 image to do this.

I read in another thread that suggested there was a v1 image for the 2025 release, but I cannot find it. Any help appreciated.

Thank you.

link_counts.title: Where do I get the 2025_v1.0 RoboRio image?

posts.cooked:
The image version doesn’t indicate which Rio it is for. As long as you are not imagining the Rio1 with the file in the “SD folder” then you’re good to go.

Use the file that shows in the imaging tool.

SD folder image is for the Rio2

posts.name: Bradford Smith
posts.cooked: Thanks, I didn’t realize the same image is good for both!

link_counts.title: LabVIEW Mecanum Drive Code for "Patient Transfer Device" (roboRIO 1)

posts.cooked:
No, it’s a specific image for each but the Rio2 image is in a different folder. Specifically look at this set of steps versus Rio1 imaging

The NI roboRIO 2.0 boots from a microSD card configured with an appropriate boot image containing the NI Linux Real-Time OS, drivers, and libraries specific to FRC. The microSD card must be imaged ...

Configuring the roboRIO: The roboRIO Imaging Tool will be used to image your roboRIO with the latest software. USB Connection: Highlights the USB Type B input at the top of the roboRIO. Connect a U...

link_counts.title: Imaging your roboRIO 1 — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation
Imaging your roboRIO 2 — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked:
I was successfully able to get my roboRIO 1 running robotpy python, by carefully following the above Imaging your roboRIO 1 instructions.

(Last year, I failed at this attempt, either the instructions improved, or I got better at following them).

Yesterday when I did the install steps, I did the “Updating Firmware” step successfully, but today, when I re-tried the steps, it failed, but the following “Imaging the roboRIO” steps succeeded (again).

Steps I took included:

Installed the 2025 FRC Game Tools

Connecting nothing to my roboRIO 1

Provided an external 12V to my roboRIO 1

Connected the USB cable to my Windows 11 PC

Ran the roboRIO Imaging Tool – The tool title line reads “ FRC roboRIO Imaging Tool - Version 25.0.1”

Selected my roboRIO Target

Followed the “Imaging the roboRIO” instructions: – Select “Format Target”, “Team Number”=9106, “Select Image”=FRC_roboRIO_2025_v2.0.zip", Click on “Reformat”

The roboRIO image was successfully updated pop-up appears, close it.

Press the “RESET” button on the roboRIO.

Switch to a windows powershell:

At the end one gets:

Run “ FRC Driver Station” App to control your roboRIO

(Edited with correction from @joe_ross ).

posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked:
Our team (like most) will use a roboRIO 2.  But, for completeness on this thread, I did find the appropriate rule.  roboRIO 1’s and 2’s are legal in competitions.

R701 *Control the ROBOT with a roboRIO. ROBOTS must be controlled via 1 programmable NI roboRIO or roboRIO 2.0 (P/N am3000 or am3000a, both versions referred to throughout this manual as “roboRIO”), with image version 2025_v2.0 or later.

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
stittrm:

The roboRIO image was successfully updated pop-up appears, close it.

Press the “RESET” button on the roboRIO.

Run the “roboRIO Team Number Setter 2025” – Enter the team number, click on “Set team to 9106” – Fiddle with it, rebooting until the name is “roboRIO-9106- FRC .local.”

What team number did it show in the succesfully updated pop-up? It shouldn’t be necessary to manually set the team number on a Rio 1.

posts.name: Mike Stitt
posts.cooked: @joe_ross Thanks for pointing this out. Retrying the install again.  And successfully using the “roboRIO Team Number Setter 2025” to refresh the team number, shows that the team number was already set to 9106.  I’ll update my steps to skip this step.
